photo.title: Ceiling Tiles

photo.description: Aachen Cathedral, frequently referred to as the "Imperial Cathedral" (in German: Kaiserdom), is a Roman Catholic church in Aachen, Germany. The church is the oldest cathedral in northern Europe and was known as the "Royal Church of St. Mary at Aachen" during the Middle Ages. For 600 years, from 936 to 1531, the Aachen chapel was the church of coronation for 30 German kings and 12 queens. Charles the Great (Charlemagne) began the construction of the Palatine Chapel around 792, along with the building of the rest of the palace structures. It was consecrated in 805 by Pope Leo III in honour of the Virgin Mary. It was extensively renovated in the 10th century and restored in 1881. The core of the cathedral is the Carolingian Palatine Chapel, which is notably small in comparison to the later additions. (c) Wikipedia
photo.tags: aachen germany deutschland cathedral kaiserdom imperialcathedral royalchurchofstmary geotagged carolingian charlesthegreat karldergrose charlemagne palatinechapel
photo.title: Aachen

photo.description: Bust of Charles the Great (Karl der Große, Charlemagne, Karolus Magnus), Treasury of the Aachen Cathedral, Germany Karl was born 742 near Herestal/Belgium, became franconian King on 10/9/768 and emperor of the holy roman empire in 12/25/800. He died on 1/28/814 and is burried in the cathedral of Aachen - the capital of his empire. His empire included most of western europe, including todays france, germany and italy. The bust was created in 1349 , commissioned by Karl IV. The crown was used at the coronation of Karl IV. The head of the bust contains the skullcap of Charles the Great. The bust shows the eagle as symbol of the holy roman empire and the french lilies. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlemagne

photo.title: Karl der Große

photo.description: I live in the town of Aachen, which is the most western city in Germany, just at the border to Belgium and the Netherlands. The picture displays a small part of the Fountain of Puppets near the great cathedral. It consists of several brass puppets that can be moved and twisted just like real puppets. The equestrian has been chosen because it is a symbol for the equestrian tradition and the annual international equestrian games CHIO (Concours Hippique International Officiel) that takes place here and Aachen is the world's most important location to host a CHIO. This is a joint work together with Yannick Flaskamp Strobist: Nikon D90 with Nikkor 85mm/1.8D lens on tripod, ISO 400 SB900 (gelled towards blue) from front right (behind the fountain), zoomed to 130mm and aimed at the water below the horse YN460 II (gelled towards orange) @1/8 through 80cm shoot-through umbrella from upper left both triggered via RF602 RF remote triggers White balance shifted manually to approx 4550K (for shifting the background ambient light towards blue)
photo.title: Fountain of Puppets (Aachen) -- Equestrian

photo.description: "Behind the rock crystal pane the bones (ulna and radius) of Charlemagne's right forearm can be seen. A document wrapped around the bones testifies that they were transferred from the shrine of Charlemagne to the reliquary on 12 October 1481. The reliquary was donated by a French king, which is indicated by the three French lilies and the crown on the coat-of-arms. King Louis XI had the reliquary made from gilt silver in Lyon. Since 1474 Charlemagne has been venerated as the progenitor of the French Kings." Excerpt from the Little Guide to the Treasury of Aachen Cathedral.
photo.tags: 1855mm cbyx cologne deutschland europe germany history k200d köln pentax tourism gold hand relic aachen justpentax pentaxart smcpda1855mmf3556al travel museum light
photo.title: The Arm Reliquary

photo.description: The Cross of Lothair dates from the 10th century and is one of the most outstanding pieces in the Aachen Treasury. The image is a little confusing, given that what we are looking at is an ancient cameo of Roman Emperor Augustus set at the centre of the crucifix surrounded by jewels. Christ does appear on the cross, but on the reverse side in the form of an engraved figure on gold plate, which may well have been used as the front of the cross, but appears far less rich than this ornate display. Which side was actually used as reverse/obverse is thus somewhat unclear! It is believe to have been donated to the cathedral by Emperor Otto III (993-1002), and is named after an engraved crystal set lower down the central shaft which carries head inscribed with the name of King Lothair II (855-869).
photo.tags: aachen treasury schatzkammer augustus cameo cross lothair jewels
photo.title: Lothair Crucifix

photo.description: Here is another shot with the little Yashica. This one I quite like although the grain (which looks almost like noise introduced by the scanner trying to lift the shadows) in the lower wood paneling is a tad too obvious. I shot this on my day in Aachen, the city bordering the Netherlands and Belgium where I spent my university years. Aachen is a beautiful little city which, although two thirds of it were destroyed during WWII, has an almost perfect and entirely car-free city center. It wraps around the Carolingian/Gothic cathedral and the old townhall whose backside faces the cathedral. This house, called Altes Posthaus, is attached to the townhall and houses a restaurant which is well-acclaimed for its steamed mussels. I was surprised to see motion blur in those two pedestrians walking by. The camera gives no indication of selected shutter speed and I did not see a warning in the viewfinder about too low a shutter speed either. The speed selected here must have been around 1/30 of a second - perfectly handholdable with a 35mm lens and a quiet and vibration-free leaf shutter. This was from the same roll of the previous shot, so it was shot on Delta 100, pushed two stops and developed in HC-110 (dilution B) for 8 minutes.
photo.tags: yashica35cc ilforddelta100 kodakhc110 pushprocessed altesposthaus aachen
photo.title: Altes Posthaus, Aachen
